text:
Let's get started. Welcome, everyone, and thank you
for being here this afternoon.

in our Office of Diversity,
Equity, and Inclusion. Their collective efforts
made this event possible.

I'm also grateful to
all of today's panelists for joining us, some of whom
specially came from cities

outside Boston to be with us
and sharing their expertise and perspective.

I'm very pleased this
discussion is occurring.

The last few months have been
difficult for Harvard Business School and for Harvard.

For many, the attacks on 10/7
and the war in Gaza afterwards,

and the recent tragedies facing
the Israeli and Palestinian people, have been felt
deeply and viscerally.

For everyone, the
history is complex, and the issues are complicated.

Today's discussion is
about educating ourselves

on these issues because,
in the words of one of today's panelists,
Dean Amaney Jamal,

this is where universities
can play a unique role.

They can, as she wrote in a
recent co-authored New York Times op ed, and I
quote, "state hard truths

and clarify critical issues. They must train the
leaders of tomorrow

to think creatively and
boldly, countering speech that

is harmful, modeling civil
dialogue, mutual respect,

and empathy, and showing
an ability to listen

to one another," end of quote. So it is listening, what I call
active listening, that I want

to encourage you to do today. Approach this conversation
with open mindedness

and a commitment to
empathy and learning.

Absorbing multiple
points of view, particularly those that are
different from your own,

is the best way to begin
to navigate uncertainties and deepen understanding.

I expect you will
hear things with which you disagree this afternoon. I urge you to look at these
moments as I do, as a gift,

an opportunity to learn about
a different perspective, and to challenge assumptions
and preconceptions.

With that, let me ask
Kristin to kick things off for us today, and thank you
for joining us this afternoon.
Thank you, Srikant.

Let me echo the welcome from
Dean Datar, both to members of the HBS community and to
the members from across Harvard

who are joining us here today. We appreciate you making the
cold walk across the river. For those of you who are
less familiar with HBS,

our mission to
educate leaders who make a difference in the
world requires three things--

an environment of trust and
mutual respect, free expression and inquiry, and a commitment
to truth, excellence,

and lifelong learning. Today's panel is a terrific
example of all three.

I also want to remind all of
our guests of our HBS community values, which we expect everyone
in this audience to uphold.

That is respect for the
rights, differences, and dignity of others,
honesty and integrity,

and accountability
for personal behavior. We ask that you refrain
from any interruption

in order to allow everyone to
get the opportunity to learn from our esteemed panelists. In that spirit, we also ask you
to please silence your phones.

Our moderator today is Tarek
Masoud, the Ford Foundation Professor of Democracy
and Governance

at the Harvard Kennedy
School, and faculty director of the Harvard Kennedy School
Middle East Initiative.

We are so grateful for his
friendship and partnership in bringing together
this esteemed panel. Please join me in
welcoming Professor Masoud
and our guests. [APPLAUSE] Thank you.

Thank you, Dean Datar and
Dean Mugford for welcoming me. I'm a humble faculty member
from a rather down market

neighborhood across the
river, and it's really quite extraordinary to
be here at the Business

School in this beautiful
venue, Klarman Hall. I want to start with a little
bit of a confession, which

is that I am sitting here
with these very notable people

in this very beautiful
space, and I'm looking out on all of you
who've gathered here

to listen to what
we have to say, and it fills me with a
bit of a sense of guilt.

And that sense of
guilt is because I know that I'm in
this beautiful space,

and that we're able to
capture the attentions of this bright and
beautiful audience because

of enormous suffering,
enormous human suffering, in a part of the world
that I and my co-panelists

happen to study. We're here because of dead
civilians, Jewish and Arab,

the former massacred
in acts of terror that were shocking in
their lurid intimacy,

and the latter massacred
in retaliations that are shocking in their scale.

Every single one
of us on this panel wishes that we actually
didn't have to be here tonight

of our collective expertise. But we hope to echo
what Dean Datar said,

that by sharing our
expertise, we can help you, our audience, concerned
citizens, future leaders

of America, after all,
you're all Harvard people, to make sense of this conflict
and to become, indeed,

part of the solution. We have with us a very
distinguished panel whose deep knowledge
of the region

and of this particular
crisis is matched by their humanity
and their empathy

with all of the peoples
caught up in it. The question we've asked
them to grapple with today

are the questions with which
we've titled this event. How did we get here, and
where are we heading?

They have a range of
views on this question. Indeed, I might even say
they disagree on the answers

to these questions but
tonight's panel isn't a debate. They're not here to score
points for this or that team.

They're here to help
us arrive at a fuller understanding of a
situation that should command all of our attentions.

What were looking for tonight is
not, in the words of the poet, the day of judgment, but
the day of understanding.

To help us achieve
that understanding, we first have
Professor Amaney Jamal, the Dean of the School of
International and Public

Affairs at Princeton University,
and the Edward Sanford professor in its department
of political science.

Dean Jamal is not
just a leader of one of our finest institutions
of higher learning.

As a Kennedy School professor,
I might say, in fact, that she's the dean of the
second best school of Public

Affairs.  But she is also a
pathbreaking scholar

of politics, whose work
documenting and explaining the structure of public
opinion, in the Arab world

and in Palestine, has
influenced legions of scholars, your humble moderator included.

She's the author of two
very important books, one on civil society
in Palestine,

the other on anti-Americanism
in the Middle East, and she's written several
very important articles.

She has won every
distinction and award that you can win in our
field and was recently

named a member of the American
Academy of Arts and Sciences. We're thrilled to
have her here today.

The next person I
want to introduce is David Makovsky, who's
the Ziegler Distinguished Fellow at the Washington
Institute for Near East Policy

and the director of
the Koret Project on Arab-Israel relations. Mr. Makovsky is somebody
who I would describe

as having consecrated
his life to helping us understand the
conflict between Israelis

and Palestinians. He spent most of that career,
the early part of his career,

as a journalist writing for such
places as the Jerusalem Post, Haaretz, which is one of
Israel's leading dailies,

and US News & World Report. In fact, I first
met Mr. Makovsky when I was in my early 20s.

I was a segment producer on a
PBS news program in the waning

years of the last millennium,
and he was a frequent guest on that show and one of the
few people who was nice to me

and treated me like a human
being, so I never forgot it. In 2013-2014, he went from
writing about the conflict

to trying to help solve it. He served as senior advisor
to the US State Department's

special envoy for
Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. He has received numerous awards
for his work, perhaps none

more important or noble than
a master's degree in Middle Eastern studies
that was bestowed

upon him from this
fine institution-- not the Business School. Other part of Harvard. And he's the author most
recently of Be Strong

and of Good Courage-- How Israel's Most
Important Leaders Shaped Its Destiny, which
he wrote with Dennis Ross.

We're thrilled to
have him today. Thank you. [APPLAUSE]

Next, we have Dr.
Khalil Shikaki, who is the director of the
Palestinian Center for Policy

and Survey Research in
Ramallah in the West Bank and a senior fellow at the
Crown Center for Middle East

Studies at Brandeis University. Dr. Shikaki earned his
doctorate in political science

from Columbia. He has had numerous
professorships in his native
Palestine, including

serving as dean of
scientific research at one of Palestine's
most notable universities,

An-Najah University in
Nablus in the West Bank. And since 1993, he has
conducted more than 200 polls

among Palestinians in the West
Bank and in the Gaza Strip. If you've ever read a
data point purporting

to explain Palestinian
public opinion, and you thought that this data
point was very insightful, you thought that the underlying
survey was well executed,

odds are that is the handiwork
of Dr. Khalil Shikaki. He is the author of
numerous research works,

including Palestinian
and Israeli Public Opinion with Jacob Shamir,
Strengthening Palestinian

Public Institutions
with Yezid Sayigh, and a book called Arabs
and Israelis Conflict

and Peacemaking in the Middle
East, which is probably the best textbook on
the Arab-Israeli crisis

that you can find. And it was written
with our next panelist,

and that is Professor
Shai Feldman. Before I introduce
Shai Feldman, I just want to make sure Khalil
gets his applause as well.

[APPLAUSE]  I didn't realize my
elegant transition

was going to do that. So Shai Feldman is a dear
friend, and the Raymond Frankel

professor of Israeli
politics and society at Brandeis University. He's a graduate of the Hebrew
University of Jerusalem,

the University of
California and Berkeley, and what Shai
Feldman has forgotten

about the
Israeli-Palestine conflict, I have not yet learned. He is one of our most prolific
and insightful scholars

of Middle Eastern politics
and security more broadly, and he's also a tremendous
institution builder.

So he is the founding
director of the Crown Center for Middle East
Studies at Brandeis,

which really is one of the
very best and most vibrant and dynamic fora for cutting
edge thinking about the Middle

East. Before building
the Crown Center, he headed the Jaffee Center
for Strategic Studies

at Tel Aviv University. And after heading the Crown
Center, from 2019 to 2022,

he was the president of Sapir
Academic College in Southern

Israel, actually near
one of the places that was targeted in Hamas's
October 7th operation.

He's written numerous
books, and he is absolutely the
first person I look to when I try to
make sense of events

in Israel, which perhaps
explains why I never host a discussion on this
issue without having him.

So please join me in
thanking and welcoming Shai.

So tonight's panel will
proceed as follows. First, I'm going to try
to engage our panelists

in conversation on the twin
questions that bring us together this evening--
how did we get here,

and where do we go from here? And then I'm going
to turn to you, our brilliant and
insightful audience,

to ask your own questions
of our distinguished panel. So first, let me just start
with how did we get here?

And I guess I'll start
with you, Dean Jamal. One of the things about the time
that we're having this panel

is that we all come here having
heard explanations about what

happened on October 7. We come here having heard
many arguments and counter

arguments, narratives and
counter narratives, accounts and opposing accounts,
and I thought

I would start by
trying to get our panel to help us pick through
some of these accounts

to figure out how we can come
to our own considered view of the events of October
7, and what has come since.

So there can't be any
reasonable disagreement about that what
happened on October 7

was deeply inhuman
and unjustifiable, but there's a lot
of disagreement

about why it happened. So no disagreement
that-- or there shouldn't be any
reasonable disagreement about what happened,
but there's disagreement

about why it happened. I was listening to the podcaster
Sam Harris the other day, and Sam Harris said,
look, this is very simple.

People who have PhDs
overly complicate it. What we observed on October
7, these atrocities,

were the direct and
straightforward result of a radical jihadist ideology.

Now, others who aren't
seeking to justify what happened will say, well,
that's overly simplistic,

and that really what happened
is a straightforward result of 16 years of siege of Gaza
and 56 years of occupation.

So we have these two narratives. How do we figure out
which of them is right, or are they both wrong?

So thank you so much
for that, Tarek, and I want to also thank the
dean and you for organizing

this wonderful event. I want to thank all of
you for turning out, and I'm looking forward to the
conversation and discussion.

So I think we don't want to
oversimplify on either side, so let's just look at what
was the status of the conflict

before October 7. So you have the Gaza Strip. It's been under
siege for 16 years.

We know that the living
conditions in Gaza are very extraordinarily
difficult,

and we were surveying-- Khalil is our partner
on the Arab barometer we were surveying and
the West Bank in Gaza

right before October 7. And literally, what we found
within that three week period,

before October 7, is
that 75% of Gazans

said that they couldn't
afford to feed their families in the 30 days before--

in the last month. So that's three out of
every four Gazans basically

struggling to feed
their children. Gaza is a densely
populated area.
It is locked. It does not control its water.

It does not control
its electricity. It does not control its Wi-Fi. The entire strip is controlled
by Israel more or less.

It also relies on about
anywhere between 300 to 400 trucks of aid per day.

So when we hear that
20 trucks of aid were entered into Gaza through
Rafah as an accomplishment

in this crisis, it's not even
scratching the surface in terms of the actual need there.

So under good conditions, daily
life in Gaza is unbearable.

This has been documented
year in and year out by the human rights
organizations,

by Palestinians themselves, by
journalists who are in Gaza. So for us who've studied
this conflict for 20 years,

if you just look at the
trend line, every three to five years, we
see bubbling up in Gaza just because of
the conditions of Gaza.

What we haven't seen is October
7, the atrocities linked to October 7, and
why did this happen?

Why did Hamas go
deep into Israel? Why did they, quote unquote,
"overreach" in this extent of--

can bracket that
because we don't want to assign assumptions there.

Nevertheless, if we're asking
about the condition of Gaza and the bubbling
of Gaza, this has

been a trend, an ongoing trend. Yeah. David, I mean, am I wrong in
thinking that these are the two

narratives that
seem to be competing for attention in the kind of
wider public opinion sphere?

And Dean Jamal points out that
they're both kind of wrong,

so what is the right account? Well, the way I
read your question-- I want to also add my
thanks to you, Tarek,

new friends. So thank you all. Thank you, everyone, for coming. I hope you can hear
me in the back okay.

Great. Cool. Look, I read your-- I don't see what
happened on October 7

as an Intifada, a mass uprising. There's a whole
context of the history,

which I'm sure we can get into. I wrote a book on Oslo. The first thing they
agreed on was Israel

wants to get out of Gaza. 1994, turn it over to
Palestinian Authority. 2005, pull out all the
settlers, which for Israel,

was a big deal to do that. And people thought, if
you don't occupy them,

then they might not love you,
but at least you're moving on. I think 2007, when Hamas really
took over, was a watershed,

and here maybe we might
have some slight differences of cause and effect because
the so-called blockade was

a focus on Hamas
saying, we're going to still fire rockets
at you, and that's what led to what it did.

Now, we'll talk about
the economic assumptions I hope in some of
the other questions. I don't want to get bogged down.

But I would say, I think
what's important for people to understand, this was a
deliberate decision making

by the Hamas leadership
to do this atrocities. The people of Gaza did not
commit these atrocities, not as

a mass movement. It was a determined set
of few at the top, who--

2,000 people, whatever
that number is that did these atrocities. And in my view, they were driven
by two big ideas, as I see it.

One big idea was a
belief that Israel-- that there could be
an axis of resistance

of all sorts of Islamist
militias loosely affiliated on different levels.

Not necessarily proxies. Some are proxies. I wouldn't call Hamas
a proxy of Iran,

who thought that this was a
moment of ultimate weakness inside Israel.

I look at Khalil, who
I adore, and I second, the best pollster hands down
on Palestinian politics.

And every trip to Ramallah,
my first stop, Khalil. The key here is understanding.

In his poll in
September, I think it is, he said 44%
of Gazans think

Israel is weak and fragmented
and on the verge of collapse.

I think that's a direct quote. Why do they think so
necessarily in 2023?

Because of the divisions over
the judicial overhaul issue. You had pilots who said they
wouldn't serve in reserve

duty, special forces, soldiers. If I was an Arab
looking inside Israel,

I would say, well, if there's
ever going to be an attack, it's going to be in 2023 because
of this sense of fragmentation.

Now, in my view, it was
a terrible misreading, a terrible miscalculation,
because Israel will unite in a time of
crisis, as it has done.

But also the poll in
Israel Democracy Institute, 70% of Israelis interpret
what happened here

as a sense of the timing. We're talking about
the timing now. Why now? Well, it's because of a
sense of an interpretation

of Israeli weakness. If you look at Mohammed Deif,
the Hamas commander, what he says the day of
the 7th, this is

the time for all the axis of
resistance to join the fight. He said that in
an audio message.

On October 15th, Abu
Marzouk and Khaled Mashal

goes on television
and says, basically, Hezbollah, what you've done
is nice, but not enough.

The battle requires more. There's a sense of disdain
that, here, we're doing it.

Where is everybody? We thought we were doing
it for the whole axis, and none of you
guys are showing up.

So that's, I think, reason one. The second reason I
would give that I see, and everyone I know I talk
to in the Arab world, Israel,

the White House, the
State Department, they all believe this, is that
this was an effort

to thwart a mega deal
of the United States, led by the Biden administration,
with Saudi Arabia,

which would be, I call it a
mega deal, a US Saudi defense treaty. But part of that deal
to get 2/3 of the Senate

Now, if you're a rejectionist
group like Hamas, you might say, if the Saudis
make peace with Israel,

now that Egypt has done
it, Jordan has done it, the United Arab
Emirates has done it. There's also been other
countries, Morocco, Bahrain,

but those are the key ones. If Saudi does it,
it's game over. And so I think part of
it was to thwart it.

Maybe to trigger
a big retaliation that would be seen on every
Arab television screen in Saudi

Arabia and in the Arab world. So I think, to me,
when you say why now? Why is the timing now?

I would say this was a
deliberate decision of Hamas looking both internally
inside Israel

and looking at the Biden
administration's priorities for a major regional
initiative that

was going to be its
signature policy going on now in the coming months.

So that's very helpful
in terms of trying to understand Hamas'
decision making

at this particular moment. I kind of think that my question
is maybe even a little bit more

basic than that, where
I'm trying to understand is if the state that this
conflict is in right now

was inevitable because both
of these narratives kind of suggest-- one of them suggests that,
as long as you have Hamas,

this is the kind of thing that
will happen because it is just hell bent on killing
Jews or eliminating

the state of Israel. And then there's another
account that's basically saying, actually, the whole
reason that Hamas is behaving

this way, the whole reason
that we're in the situation that we're in, is because
of a set of policies

over the last 16, over the
last 50 years, whatever, that not just immiserate
Palestinians, as Professor

Jamal has pointed
out, but maybe even undermine moderates and
allow radicals like Hamas

to get the upper hand. So I guess that's the question
I think lots of people who

are reading this,
lots of my students, these are the accounts that
they're trying to grapple with. Khalil Shikaki, can you help
us adjudicate between them.

Sure, I can try. I think there are
three questions here. One is the overall environment.

Was this overall environment
leading in this direction or not? The second is the
Hamas decision making,

and the third is the timing. These are three separate
issues, but perhaps the most

fundamental is the first. Of course, the Jordanian
foreign minister, who said Hamas
did not invent the conflict. The conflict invented Hamas.

Since the Oslo
process started, we have seen Israelis
and Palestinians

trying to reach an end to the
conflict, a two state solution.

The current Israeli
government, led by Netanyahu, is the same government
that has been trying,

for most of the last 16
years, to create conditions, or to support conditions, that
have essentially prevented

any progress in that direction. Hamas was very
instrumental in providing

that kind of environment. The Palestinian division means
there is no serious discussion

about a two state solution
or ending the conflict, and so Israel and Hamas found
themselves in the same bed

for the last 16 years. Hamas has been
nourished by this logic,

the logic of how to
prevent a two state solution from coming about.

That is why Hamas became
stronger and stronger because the Netanyahu
governments have

done their best to make sure
that the Palestinians remain divided, and that there is no
serious discussion about ending

the Israeli occupation. This is the source of all
evil in this whole story,

that there is occupation that
we are not able to get rid of, and the Palestinians
want to get rid of that.

But then there is
Hamas decision making. The Hamas decision making
cannot be read without looking

at the history of
these 16 years. What has Hamas been trying
to do during these 16 years?

We can't just look at what
Hamas is saying today, as you have done, David, as an
explanation for their behavior.

We have already 16 years
of their control over Gaza in which we can see
what direction they

have been trying
to find a solution to their own predicament.

but since then, they have been
trying to figure out a way out, an exit for them out of the
predicament they put themselves

in. And the initial impulse was
to have a mini state in Gaza of their own for the time being,
and that state of mini state

would have access through Egypt. This is why they had
hundreds of tunnels underneath Egypt, underneath
the Gaza-Egypt borders,

so that they can have a
kind of political economy that can sustain
that kind of outcome.

A mini state in Gaza-- that's what they have done
between 2007 and 2014.

In 2014, with Sisi
in power, Sisi closed down 99% of the tunnels
that the previous regime

or regimes allowed in place. With that completely destroyed,
the idea of a mini state

was destroyed, and
the Hamas started to look for an
alternative strategy.

The alternative exit for
them was through the-- going back to the
Palestinian Authority,

allowing the reunification
of the West Bank and Gaza, and now, we have a
period between 2014

all the way until 2021 with
new Hamas leaderships that

have, in fact, done
everything in its power to give the
Palestinian Authority

everything the Palestinian
Authority asked for so that the West Bank
and Gaza can be reunified.

Sinwar, the man who led
this last offensive, is the man who gave
Abbas, the president

of the Palestinian Authority,
everything that Abbas wanted

so that he could reunify
the West Bank and Gaza, and Abbas failed. In April 2021, Abbas
canceled the elections

that were Sinwar's means of
getting to the reunification,

so that Hamas can
be reintegrated once again into the Palestinian
formal political process.

That was Sinwar's way out. That was different from those
who actually carried out

the violent takeover
of Gaza, who's goal was a mini state
in Gaza through Egypt.

Abbas destroyed that option. Sisi destroyed the
first, and it was

Abbas who destroyed the second. Between 2021 all the way
until October the 6th,

Sinwar's eyes looked at
Netanyahu and Israel, and not just Netanyahu, but also the
two previous prime ministers

before Netanyahu, Lapid and
Bennett, for a third exit. And the third exit was to go
back to the idea of a mini

state that now Hamas has come
to the conclusion that Abbas cannot be trusted, and
he is not going to allow

the reunification of
the West Bank and Gaza. They have to have their own
mini state in Gaza, but instead

of Egypt being the exit,
Netanyahu and Israel became the exit, that
Israel would offer them

an end to the siege and blockade
in return for allowing Hamas

to control Gaza and
maintain security for Gazans

and for Israelis. This is the deal that
previous Israeli government

have been trying to
reach with Hamas that I think have gained significant
grounds starting with late 21.

With the formation of the most
extreme Israeli government early this year, Sinwar's
goal of reaching a mini state

in Gaza was
completely demolished, and he now was left
without any way out.

The most difficult part
for the Israeli government was how to give Sinwar
the legitimation needed

to be able to have a
mini state in Gaza. And that legitimation
was a huge success

in releasing
Palestinian prisoners. The issue of
Palestinian prisoners has been the most fundamental
issue of legitimacy

for any Palestinian leader. That's what Sinwar wanted. He could not get that
with the kind of prisoners

he had before October 7. The plan for Sinwar,
the offensive,

was to achieve many things,
but most importantly, to hurt Israel, to force it to come
to the negotiating table,

to have enough prisoners
so that he can have a huge success in releasing
prisoners so that the West

Bank will give him legitimacy
to have a mini state in Gaza. Gazans wanted a mini state.

West Bankers rejected
it completely. Having that kind of
success would have

given Sinwar what he wanted. The timing was affected
by the Saudi deal.

He did not want the
Saudis and the Israelis to reach a deal, leaving
him hanging in limbo.

He was influenced by what
was happening in Israel. The judiciary, he was
influenced by what

was happening in the West
Bank, the rise of armed groups, because Israel was sending
its army to the West Bank

rather than defending
its own borders in Gaza. That is the timing,
but it has nothing

to do with the fundamental
goals of what Hamas has been trying to do for 16 years.

So that's really very
important because you've offered a narrative
of Hamas basically

as a rational
actor, whose goal is to try to set up a
mini state in Gaza

and having the door slammed
shut by the Egyptians-- Israel treated it exactly
like that for 16 years.

This is not a new narrative. This is how Israel dealt
with Hamas for 16 years.

Shai, do you sign on to the
narrative-- or the analysis
offered by your co-author? You put me on the spot here.

So first of all, I
want to say this. I think that we have
to differentiate

between general conditions that
allow a development to take

place, and the specific
circumstances that affect the timing, and
they're not the same.

I think that, put it this way,
Israel's position on Hamas is,

and by the way, I could
proceed everything I say by saying I agree with
my first three panelists.

I think every one of them
had a piece of the truth,

but the problem is that this
is a very complex story. And it's not very easy
to basically identify

which parts are-- or at least, which parts I
agree with and which not.

I think that it goes back to
your first two narratives.

You cannot look at this without
giving at least some weight

to the fact that Israel was
dealing with a neighbor that ideologically was committed
to Israel's destruction,

and it never changed
its narrative. It's not the PLO.

The PLO gradually, from
1974 through the phase plan,

to 1988, the Declaration
of Independence, then Oslo, it gradually
changed its narrative.

And it made the relationship
between the Palestinians, led by the PLO and Israel, no
longer a zero sum game.

Hamas has never gone
through this same journey,

and the problem is that Israel
weighed then all these issues

regarding, for example,
the so-called siege-- Israel weighed
this issue of siege

through this prism of the fact
that it landed with a neighbor. And I'll get to whether
that neighbor also played--

was a convenient tool for a
certain narrative in Israel,

but a neighbor
that was committed to Israel's destruction. So some of the things
that Israel accepted

when it dealt with the PLO-- in 1998, President
Clinton came to Gaza

and inaugurated an international
airport and the beginning of a port in Gaza.

The minute that
Hamas took over-- and we have to remember,
this is somehow a plurality of
Palestinians, somehow

a plurality of Palestinians

they're equitable. Hamas is a terrorist group.

Let's not debate about that. But you can't have
a ruling coalition that's talking-- that
has people advocating

for the killing of Arabs on
the West Bank in Gaza as well. Yeah. I mean-- Yeah.

David, yes, quickly. I just want to say really
briefly, something Shai alluded to at the very end that I was
worried got lost, people say

how did the Likud come to power? And I think it's very
important to understand, are there a minority
of these settlers,

by the way, but a
violent minority that should be thwarted. And I worry about it
igniting the West Bank,

and I think you and I see
that very similarly, Amaney. But let's be clear,
the reason why

the Likud, that got only 12
seats in 2006, came to power is because the public lost
faith in the basic equation

that we all want, which
is, if you withdraw, you're more secure. You're not more vulnerable.

If we had rockets coming from
downtown Boston on Cambridge, and we couldn't solve
this, we would not

get the peace process
people to succeed, the camp of people in
America that I'm very with.

The equation has to be, if you
withdraw, you're more secure. You're not more vulnerable.

The Likud has won because people
don't believe in the equation. They think we're do-gooders from
Harvard University or something

who really don't understand
the harsh reality that Hamas will fire rockets because
they are rejectionist.

They don't accept Israel
the size of a telephone booth on a Tel Aviv beach. But you don't have
Hamas on the West Bank.

First of all-- Hamas West Bank did not join-- Hamas Gaza has been calling for
Hamas West Bank to join them,

and they have not. My point is that-- Amaney, you know this, 2005,
when Israel pulled out-- No, no, we had the right-wing
radicals who did suicide.

I'm not going to argue
about the history. But I am going to disagree with
you, David, as a colleague, and I'm worried, I'll
be honest with you.

When our policymakers are
saying it's a fait accompli,

there was this moment in
peace, and we're never going back to it because you
had these suicide bombers who

we denounced as
terrorists, and the-- The story's the opposite. No, no, you want to
contextualize right wing

extremism in Israel,
but you don't want to then understand then
how this also contributed

to the extremists in Palestine. What I'm trying to say, we need
now leaders to say, our youth--

Of course. 50% of Palestinians in
the West Bank in Gaza were not born before--

were born after
the 2006 elections. We keep saying the
2006 elections.

50% were born after
that election. Let's give the children
of Israel and Palestine a better future.

Let's get over-- yes, let's-- I agree. OK. We agree on that. But we don't want everybody--
everybody keeps saying, well,

we did everything, and
they did, they did-- No, I said, we've got to
keep trying for two states. We should never give up because
we want dignity for both.

But we just have to realize
that we should not demonize half of the Israeli public.

No, we're not being-- is it legitimate
to say that people

in the Israeli
coalition government-- [INTERPOSING VOICES] The moderator is losing
control of this panel. Who call for the killing
and eradication of Arabs.

What? What did you say? The moderator is losing
control of this panel, and he would like
to reassert it.

But this is a great
debate, and I would love it to keep happening. It's just, I want to get to
as many questions as we can.
Khalid has not said anything. I know. [LAUGHING] Khalid might try. Please.

Thank you all for your time. My name's Adam Schneider. I'm a joint degree law and
Kennedy School student.

So after this war ends,
and the dust settles, and God willingly
soon, there's going to be another push for peace.

Israel will hold elections,
and almost certainly will have new leadership,
but I think there's a real question of
legitimacy right

now for Palestinian
Authority leadership coming to those future
peace negotiations.

Abbas in the 18th year
of a four year term, he doesn't have much
legitimacy outside of Ramallah.

What steps can the
international community take to help restore
PA legitimacy?

And if there is an election,
how do we address concerns that a repeat of 06 won't happen,
and a group like Hamas or worse
could come to power? That's a great question. I'd love Khalil to address that.

Who told you Abbas has
legitimacy in Ramallah? That's news to me.

He certainly does not
have legitimacy anywhere. The survey that we have
done that Amaney referred to

in the West Bank showed 85%
of West Bankers wanting--

demanding his resignation. Only 6% of West Bankers
were willing to re-elect him

if elections are held today. There is no doubt that we need
a national unity government

for the Palestinians
right now, one that can stabilize conditions
both in the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip and
can prepare for elections.

And in the meanwhile, we
need to see strong leadership from this country, and from
the major Arab countries,

particularly those that
have made peace with Israel, to come up with a plan
for a two state solution

that the two sides
can embrace, one that will respect the
needs of both sides

and will respect
everything-- all the progress that has already been made. In that context, I can't see
anyone calling for violence

being able to win in
Palestinian elections. Palestinians will
vote for Hamas only

if they think that diplomacy
and negotiations are not viable and that the only way for them
to end the Israeli occupation

is through violence. If we can convince them
that is not the case, I can't see them
voting for Hamas.

I can't see that problem
arising to begin with. Nonetheless, if Hamas is
to win, this is democracy.

We have to accept that. In Israel, Israel has now
the most extreme government

that is thinking about
bombing Gaza out of this world

and annexing the entire West
Bank and we're OK with that.

But if Hamas wins,
we're not OK with that? Certainly, we need, if we
want to be real Democrats,

we have to accept if Hamas wins. Nonetheless, if we look at
the history, the surveys

that I've been doing throughout
all these years have always indicated, every time the
Palestinians thought that there

was a viable diplomatic
path to a two state solution that would end the
Israeli occupation,

they voted for
those Palestinians who supported democracy
and supported negotiations

and a two state solution. They only voted
for Hamas when they thought that there was
absolutely no way forward

through diplomacy
and negotiations. Shai, I want to take the
opportunity of the gentleman's

question in his mention of
the international community to come to you and ask
you what role do you

see the international community,
the Arab countries, the United States playing in
trying to get us out

of the immediate catastrophe
that we're in right now? No one's going to get you out
of the immediate catastrophe.

The issue is, what would
the day after look like?

And I do think that,
again, I think we have to go back to first principles.

The first principle was
Israel signed an agreement with the Palestinian
Liberation Organization

after Israel regarded that
organization, for decades, as a terrorist organization.

But it recognized
the fact that the PLO went through certain changes
and became a partner.

And even Prime Minister
Netanyahu, when it won right

at the end of one of
those negotiation episodes called the Wye River
negotiations in '98,

there was a ceremony
in the White House. And Prime Minister Netanyahu
called Arafat "my partner."

So the issue now is, so
let's go back to principles. Israel agreed to hand
the Palestinians,

gradually, control over the
Palestinian territories. The PLO was decided by
the Arab League in 1974

as the only legitimate voice
of the Palestinian people. Now, what does it take?

Something very bad happened
to the PA through these years, as Khalil is better
than anybody to describe

what happened there. So they can't take
over right now.

They can't take over because
they're not legitimate, and because they have no power. So the issue is, is it
possible for, again,

a coalition of countries that
have some kind of a track record in relations with
Israel, whether it's

Egypt and Jordan and the four
Abraham Accords countries and Saudi Arabia that was almost
on the verge of normalization

to say, we, for a certain
period, we do two things. Number one, we take over
Gaza, and number two,

we will fill the
shopping list of what does it take to strengthen
the PA with an agreed

upon timetable, after which
there will be elections. They will elect their leaders,
and so on and so forth.

I want to say only one
more thing about what does it take because I think we
kind of a little bit diverted.

We are now faced
with a disaster,

the dimensions of which we
have not seen since 1948. It's a disaster on
the Israeli side.

It's a catastrophic--
it's a catastrophe on the Palestinian side in Gaza. Now, I see, and that
goes back to the first

of the questions that was
asked when we said, well, what can happen now? I can see, because
Israel, again,

with all the criticism
that can be leveled against Israeli policy
and Israeli leaders

and so on and so forth,
I can tell you that--

I'll race with anybody in
this auditorium as to-- in the sport of criticizing
the Israeli government.

But there is one
virtue, and I call it a virtue, of the
Israeli political system.

Israel is not-- is an
unforgiving country to itself.

Every time it faced
a catastrophe-- the biggest one of this
dimension was the 73 surprise.

It nominates a national
commission of inquiry, and if you look just the
second Lebanon war in 2006,

the National Commission of
inquiry basically sacked-- the political
leadership was finished,

and they sacked all the
top echelons of the IDF for its malperformance.

What will happen now, parallel
to what can save Gaza, is after--

in the day after, there will
be a major, major reckoning on the Israeli side because
Israel is never, ever forgave.

Now, you see, the
problem is this. We-- and I say we.

It's Israelis and
Palestinians and especially "we" is Israel
and Gaza or Hamas.

We both arrived at
this catastrophe. I can see a process in Israel
where people-- and that

was the real virtue. The real virtue was that fire,
people who were named as liable

or as to be blamed,
and so on and so forth. The real reckoning is
to go back and reexamine

your assumptions that
led to a policy that led to the catastrophe. I have much more--

I have confidence that
Israel will go through this because it has-- it's almost a national sport.

I wish I could be
that optimistic about the Palestinians going
through a similar reckoning

and asking themselves,
but this Israeli army that came into Gaza and started
leveling neighborhoods in Gaza,

they didn't do it
all these years. Why did they do it? Maybe we had something--
we, which is to say,

we Palestinians, maybe we
Hamas, had something to--

some responsibility in this. It didn't come out of
nowhere because you see, the problem is,
usually, is that--

and that's the way
some Europeans, other Arab countries,
sometimes treat Europeans--

treat Palestinians as
if they have no agency. If I were a Palestinian, I
would be infuriated by this

because it's almost the
Palestinians are children that you only talk to grownups,
and you don't expect anything

is both sides have to face the
fact that they both contributed to this catastrophe,
and they have to--

it's not a matter of, oh,
we'll get rid of Abbas, and we'll get rid of Bibi. No, no, it's the question of
what was the assumptions that

led to Israeli policy? What led to the Palestinians
to behave the way they-- and here again, look,
the Palestinians

have a lot to reckon
with because-- and forget about what
happened in October 7.

Four Arab countries that didn't

with Israel without--

and set the Palestinians aside. The Saudis themselves were-- It can't be that the
Palestinians can just

complain about
the Arab countries having abandoned them, betrayed
them, stabbed them in the back.

Palestinians have
to, at one point, sit down and say, how did we
contribute to this happening?

Amaney Jamal, I
see saw you nodding when he said that what's
needed is self-criticism on both sides.

100%. I mean, we're not-- I think we've never come here
to say that Palestinians have

never done anything
wrong in the history, or what Hamas did was right. And if you think,
with all due respect,

that Israelis are
infuriated, we're very infuriated

was going to get pummeled.

This was a discussion,
a conversation, but these children
in Gaza, again, half of them who weren't

they are victims
of this conflict, which is where we begin with. We're all victims
of this conflict. There needs to be a

and I hope that, if we can move
beyond, hopefully, October 7--

and like Shai said, that
moment is very catastrophic. When we get to

to allow the younger voices and
their dreams and aspirations some room, because
if we're stuck

on the past and talk about
2002 and 2004 and 2006, those narratives
can be battled out.

But there needs to be sort of-- but we need to be working
together as communities.

Yeah, this is great. Now, we're two minutes over. One thing that

has learned, that you never
